p.s: after reading The Hate U Give twice, I have a very clear opinion / answer to your question: Everyevery teenager - no matter if it comes from the US or not - should read this novel!

First of all it shows that police violence and rasismracism is still a big problem in America, but - and I think this is even the better argument - it highlights a perspective from a girl who dodoes not know where her place in the world is or who she even is and gets in a situation where a cop - who should protect the girl - kills her friend.
And I am sure that nearly every teenager knows this feeling of being self confused and in a situation which can not get.

I think it is very important to read this novel in school to udnerstand the kind of slang and to work on the right understanding, because yes, sometimes it is a bit vulgar or contains offensive language.
But I hvae to say: the novel would not have touched me that much if it weren't this kind of language.
It makes the novel authentic, realistic and it makes Starr to a person to identify with, because every teenager has his own language.
The fact that your school board wants to hide the novel and then obviously the reality makes me very sad.
This novel is a great chance to understand eachother and to finally make all Americans equal.
I did not know anything about rasismracism in America, I first came in touch with George Floyd.
The Hate U Give has helped me to understand what is going on in America and how the black people feel.
So please, Lisa make sure that you read The Hate U Give.
